# {Category}

Overview:

As the threat landscape continues to grow in complexity, cyberdefenders require to make sense of the multiplicity of signals that are generated by security solutions covering different threat vectors. The ability of a SIEM solution to aggregate data from multiple sources, analyse and generate high fidelity incidents is of paramount importance. SIEM solutions accomplish this desired outcome via the process of event correlation. The ability to correlate various log sources is perhaps one of the most powerful features of a SIEM. This is because correlation brings out more relevant context and insights by stitching together events that on their own may pass as benign but taken together in a particular sequence or conditions could be uncover nefarious activity. Correlation in Microsoft Sentinel can be achieved broadly using the ‚Äòjoin‚Äô or ‚Äòunion‚Äô commands with each of the commands having various flavors depending on the use-case to be fulfilled. Below is a summary of flavours available via the correlation options:
Summary of 'join' flavors
|No|Type |Output schema | |--|---------------|--------------------| |1|kind=leftanti, kind=leftantisemi|Returns all the records from the left side that don't have matches from the right| |2|kind=rightanti, kind=rightantisemi|Returns all the records from the right side that don't have matches from the left.| |3|kind unspecified, kind=innerunique |Only one row from the left side is matched for each value of the on key. The output contains a row for each match of this row with rows from the right.| |4|kind=leftsemi|Returns all the records from the left side that have matches from the right.| |5 |kind=rightsemi|Returns all the records from the right side that have matches from the left.| |6|kind=inner|Contains a row in the output for every combination of matching rows from left and right.| |7|kind=leftouter (or kind=rightouter or kind=fullouter)|Contains a row for every row on the left and right, even if it has no match. The unmatched output cells contain nulls.
Summary of 'union' flavors
|No|Type |Output schema | |--|---------------|--------------------| |1|inner|The result has the subset of columns that are common to all of the input tables.| |2|outer|(default). The result has all the columns that occur in any of the inputs. Cells that weren't defined by an input row are set to null. - [join](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/joinoperator?pivots=azuredataexplorer) - [union](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/unionoperator?pivots=azuredataexplorer) - [project](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/projectoperator)
I want to:

links.linkLabel: 1. Combine and query data from two tables with a common field
2. Combine and query all records from multiple tables

content.json:
## 1. Combine and query data from two tables with a common field

     Operators to be used:

      **- [join](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/joinoperator?pivots=azuredataexplorer)**       **- [union](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/unionoperator?pivots=azuredataexplorer)**

     Sample queries:

**      - Returns a list of records from the SecurityEvent and SecurityAlert tables that share a matching computer name **

         SecurityEvent
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(1d)
         | join (SecurityAlert) on SourceComputerId| join (SecurityAlert) on SourceComputerId

**      - Returns a list of records from the DeviceInfo and DeviceLogoon tables that havea matchin DeviceName **

         DeviceInfo
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(1d)
         | join (DeviceLogonEvents) on $left.DeviceName == $right.DeviceName

         This query requires the DeviceInfo and DeviceLogonEvents

     Sample use cases:

**      - Detect whether admin accounts are being used on Windows Endpoints. This use case requires DeviceInfo logs from Microsoft 365 Defender **

         DeviceInfo
         | where TimeGenerated >ago(1d)
         | where OSPlatform !contains "Server"
         | join DeviceLogonEvents on $left.DeviceName == $right.DeviceName
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(1d)
         | where AccountName in ('Administrator','Admin')
         | project DeviceName, OSPlatform, LogonType, AccountName

**      - Detect virtual machines on which a logon type of 'Network' was registered **

         SecurityEvent
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(1d)
         | where AccountType == "Machine" and LogonType == 3
         | project Computer, AccountType, TargetAccount, Level
         | join (ServiceMapComputer_CL | where TimeGenerated > ago(1d)
         project Computer, Ipv4Addresses_s, FullDisplayName_s, VirtualizationState_s
         | where VirtualizationState_s == "virtual") on Computer

Check out the relevant samples found in Microsoft Sentinel:

####       Analytics Rules:       **- [Possible contact with a domain generated by a DGA](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/76578d41f67181e6c1acb16b520f48a31d248036/Detections/CommonSecurityLog/MultiVendor-PossibleDGAContacts.yaml)**       **- [Anomalous login followed by Teams action](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/06832a873e1686244f0bc02b10f79ba879078864/Detections/MultipleDataSources/AnomalousIPUsageFollowedByTeamsAction.yaml)**       **- [Failed logon attempts in authpriv](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/06832a873e1686244f0bc02b10f79ba879078864/Detections/Syslog/FailedLogonAttempts_UnknownUser.yaml)** ####       Hunting Queries:       **- [Azure Active Directory sign-in burst from multiple locations](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/158019e9f69d847f506d2f1ba05af0bad64b66dd/Hunting%20Queries/SigninLogs/signinBurstFromMultipleLocations.yaml)**       **- [Unused or Unsupported Cloud Regions](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/c69fda6e8b90aa3ae797560b670a42fa8fce2859/Hunting%20Queries/AWSCloudTrail/AWS_Unused_UnsupportedCloudRegions.yaml)**       **- [User Login IP Address Teleportation](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/158019e9f69d847f506d2f1ba05af0bad64b66dd/Hunting%20Queries/SigninLogs/UserLoginIPAddressTeleportation.yaml)**       **- [Potential DGA detected](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/76578d41f67181e6c1acb16b520f48a31d248036/Hunting%20Queries/DnsEvents/DNS_HighPercentNXDomainCount.yaml)** ####       Workbook:       **- [Identity & Access](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/83c6d8c7f65a5f209f39f3e06eb2f7374fd8439c/Workbooks/IdentityAndAccess.json)** ####       Playbook:       **- [Endpoint enrichment - Carbon Black](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/bf839dd241e33fc253eec60db94e9eb6000bc7a9/Playbooks/CarbonBlack/Playbooks/CarbonBlack-DeviceEnrichment/azuredeploy.json)**

## 2. Combine and query records from multiple tables

     Operators to be used:

      **- [union](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/unionoperator?pivots=azuredataexplorer)**       **- [count()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/count-aggfunction)**       **- [sort](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/sortoperator)**

     Sample queries:

**      - Returns list of records from two tables with multiple common fields**

         let UpdateSum=UpdateSummary
         | project Computer, OsVersion, ResourceGroup;
         let Updt = Update
         | project Computer, ComputerEnvironment, ResourceGroup, Type, Title, UpdateState;
         union withsource="SourceTable" UpdateSum, Update
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(1d)

**      - Returns a list all tables with data in the workspace showing the record count for each **

         union withsource=table *
         | summarize count() by table
         | sort by table asc

**      - Combine multiple tables to produce a result set with a subset of columns that are common to all of the input tables**

         UpdateSummary
         | union kind=inner Update


     Sample use cases:

**      - Returns a list vulnerabilities from Microsoft Defender for Endpoint that have a severity level of ‚ÄúCritical‚Äù or ‚ÄúHigh‚Äù with a CVSS
         score of greater than 7 and have a known public exploit **

         DeviceTvmSoftwareVulnerabilities
         | where VulnerabilitySeverityLevel == 'Critical' or VulnerabilitySeverityLevel == 'High'
         | join kind=inner (DeviceTvmSoftwareVulnerabilitiesKB) on CveId | where IsExploitAvailable !=0 and CvssScore > 7

**      - The query will return a list of any accounts that were created but have never been used even once over the past 90 days **

         IdentityInfo
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(30d)
         | where AccountCreationTime < ago(90d) //filter out anything that was created earlier than 90
         | where isnotempty(AccountCreationTime) //confirm no blanks
         | where isempty(DeletedDateTime) //account was not deleted after it was created
         | where IsAccountEnabled == true // confirm account is not disabled
         | join kind=leftanti (SigninLogs | where TimeGenerated > ago(90d)) on $left.AccountUPN == $right.UserPrincipalName

# {Category}

Overview:

A key function of a SIEM solution is to detect deviations from the norm that might represent malicious activity in one‚Äôs environment. Anomaly detections can be particularly useful in uncovering threats that do not lend themselves to detection by traditional rule-based analytics. Thankfully, KQL does come with built-in anomaly detection functions that make the process of building anomaly detection queries that much easier.
I want to:

links.linkLabel: 1. Detect anomalies within time series data
2. Detect outliers within time series data
3. Detect anomalous activities based on built-in customizable rules

content.json:
## 1. Detect anomalies within time series data

     Operators to be used:

      **- [series_decompose_anomalies()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/series-decompose-anomaliesfunction?WT.mc_id=Portal-fx)**       **- [series_outliers()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/series-outliersfunction?WT.mc_id=Portal-fx)**       **- [series_fit_line()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/series-fit-linefunction)**       **- [make-series](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/make-seriesoperator)**

     Sample queries:

**      1. Create a Time series across 30 days with samples taken over 1 day intervals**

         SigninLogs
         | make-series Trend=count() default=0 on TimeGenerated in range(startofday(ago(30d)), now(), 1d) by UserPrincipalName

         Data may not be available in LA Demo

**      2. Create a Time series across 30 days with samples taken over 1 day intervals, then plot a chart to visualize the distribution**

         SecurityEvent
         | make-series Trend=count() default=0 on TimeGenerated in range(startofday(ago(30d)), now(), 1d) by UserPrincipalName
         | extend (anomalies, score, baseline) = series_decompose_anomalies(Trend, 1.5, -1, 'linefit')
         | render timechart


         Sample output would look like below:

     

     Sample use cases:

**      - Detect the creation of an anomaulous number of resources**

         AzureActivity
         | where TimeGenerated >= ago(30d)
         | where OperationName == "Create or Update Virtual Machine" or OperationName == "Create Deployment";
         | make-series num = dcount(ResourceId) default=0 on EventSubmissionTimestamp in range(ago(30d), now(), 1d) by Caller
         | where ResultDescription =~ "User did not pass the MFA challenge (non interactive)."
         | extend (flag, score, baseline) = series_decompose_anomalies(Trend)
         failedMFAChallengeLogons
         | make-series Trend=count() default=0 on TimeGenerated in range(startofday(ago(30d)), now(), 1d) by UserPrincipalName
         | extend (flag, score, baseline) = series_decompose_anomalies(Trend)
         | extend outliers=series_outliers(num, "ctukey", 0, 10, 90)
         | project-away num
         | mvexpand outliers
         | where outliers > 0.9
         | summarize by Caller
         

**      - Detect authentication attempts from an unusually large number of locations**

         SigninLogs
         | where TimeGenerated >= ago(30d)
         | extend locationString= strcat(tostring(LocationDetails["countryOrRegion"]), "/", tostring(LocationDetails["state"]), "/",
          tostring(LocationDetails["city"]), ";")
         | project TimeGenerated, AppDisplayName , UserPrincipalName, locationString
         | make-series dLocationCount = dcount(locationString) on TimeGenerated in range(startofday(ago(30d)),now(), 1d) by UserPrincipalName,
          AppDisplayName| extend (RSquare,Slope,Variance,RVariance,Interception,LineFit)=series_fit_line(dLocationCount)
         | where Slope >0.3
         

**      - Returns a number of tables from your workspace that have experienced an anomalous ingestion in relation to the established
         baseline over the past 30 days**

         let UpperThreshold = 3.0;
         let MinimunIngestionPerDay = 50;
         let MinimumPercentageIncrease = 30;
         Usage
         | where IsBillable == "true"
         | make-series Qty=sum(Quantity) on TimeGenerated from ago(30d) to now() step 1d by DataType
         | extend (anomalies, score, baseline) = series_decompose_anomalies(Qty, 1.5, 0, 'linefit', 1, 'ctukey',0.01)
         | where anomalies[-1] == 1 or anomalies[-1] == -1
         | extend Score = score[-1]
         | where Score >= UpperThreshold
         | extend PercentageQtyIncrease = ((round(todouble(Qty[-1]),0)-round(todouble(baseline[-1]),1))/round(todouble(Qty[-1]),0) * 100)
         | project DataType,ExpectedQty=round(todouble(baseline[-1]),0), ActualQty=round(todouble(Qty[-1]),0),round(PercentageQtyIncrease,0)
         | order by round(todouble(PercentageQtyIncrease),0) desc
         | where ActualQty >=MinimunIngestionPerDay and PercentageQtyIncrease >= 30
         | summarize count() by Account

## 2. Detect outliers within Timeseries data

     Operators to be used:

      **- [materialize()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/materializefunction)**       **- [make-series](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/make-seriesoperator)**       **- [dcount()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/dcount-aggfunction)**       **- [range](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/rangeoperator)**       **- [summarize](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/summarizeoperator)**       **- [iif()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/iiffunction)**       **- [avg](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/avg-aggfunction)**       **- [project-away](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/projectawayoperator)**       **- [autocluster()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/autoclusterplugin#:~:text=autocluster%20finds%20common%20patterns%20of%20discrete%20attributes%20%28dimensions%29,can%20potentially%20work%20on%20any%20filtered%20data%20set.)**       **- [basket()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/basketplugin)**

     Sample query:

**      1. Plot a chart to show deviation/outliers from expected pattern of input values **

         range x from 1 to 1 step 1
          | project x=range(bin(now(), 1h)-11h, bin(now(), 1h), 1h) , y=dynamic([2,5,6,8,11,15,17,18,25,26,30,30])
         | extend (RSquare,Slope,Variance,RVariance,Interception,LineFit) = series_fit_line(y)
         | render timechart

     Sample use case:

**      - Detect whether the operation of "Create role assignment" was performed by an expected identity in Azure**

         AzureActivity
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(30d)
         | where OperationName == "Create role assignment"
         | where ActivityStatus == "Succeeded"
         | project Caller, CallerIpAddress
         | evaluate basket()
         | join kind=leftouter (AzureActivity // include all records from left but only matched from the right
         | where OperationName == "Create role assignment"
         | where ActivityStatus == "Succeeded"
         | summarize StartTime = min(TimeGenerated), EndTime = max(TimeGenerated) by Caller, CallerIpAddress) on Caller, CallerIpAddress
         | project-away Caller1, CallerIpAddress1
         | where isnotempty(StartTime)
         | extend timestamp = StartTime, AccountCustomEntity = Caller, IPCustomEntity = CallerIpAddress
         | project timestamp, AccountCustomEntity, IPCustomEntity, Percent

## 3. SOC Machine Learning rules

     Built-in rule description:

Anomalies are saved to the new Anomalies table in your Microsoft Sentinel workspace. No alerts or incidents are generated by these anomalies. Use these anomalies to correlate with other signals to build threat detections, investigate an incident, or hunt for malicious actors. For a more detailed description of the anomaly rules, go [here](https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/azure-sentinel/democratize-machine-learning-with-customizable-ml-anomalies/ba-p/2346338). All these rules are available with the Microsoft Sentinel Analytics blade. However, one cannot edit the KQL logic behind them but they are customizable via the user interface.

     Sample query:

**      1. Correlate and trigger an incident based on events in the anomalies table**

         Anomalies
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(14d)
         | extend upn_split=split(UserName,"\\")
         | extend Uname = tostring(upn_split[1])
         | extend AnomUpn=strcat(Uname,"@seccxp.ninja")
         | extend AnomScore = tostring(AnomalyDetails.Score)
         | join SigninLogs on $left.AnomUpn == $right.UserPrincipalName
         | where toreal( AnomScore) > 0.02

# {Category}

Overview:

SIEM solutions require to collect and analyze data from several sources. As such, some of the needed data is not always presented in a structured format while in its raw state. Therefore, it may be necessary to perform some pre-processing operations on the data in order to transform it into a format that allows you to query it in a more granular manner or make it possible to correlate using a language such as Kusto Query Language (KQL) or Regular Expression constructs (Regex).

content.json:
## 1. Extract entities from fields in logs

     Operators to be used:

      **- [extend](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/extendoperator)**       **- [extract_all](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/extractallfunction)**       **- [mv-apply](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/mv-applyoperator)**       **- [isnotempty()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/isnotemptyfunction)**       **- [tostring()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/tostringfunction)**       **- [join](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/joinoperator?pivots=azuredataexplorer)**       **- [parse](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/distinctoperator)**       **- [parse_json](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/parsejsonfunction)**       **- [distinct](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/distinctoperator)**

     Sample queries:

**      - Extract Hostname from Entity field(JSON) in SecurityAlert table**

         SecurityAlert
         | where Entities has "HostName"
         | extend entities = todynamic(Entities)
         | mv-apply Entity = entities on (
           where Entity.Type == "host"
         | extend HostName = Entity.HostName)
         | project HostName, AlertName, Description , TimeGenerated

         SecurityAlert
         | where Entities has "HostName"
         | extend HostName = extract_all('"HostName"\\s*:\\s*"([^"]*)"', Entities)
         | project HostName, AlertName, Description , TimeGenerated

**      - Extract City, State and Country from LocationDetails field (dynamic) in Signin Logs**

         SigninLogs
         | project TimeGenerated, UserPrincipalName, StatusCode=Status.errorCode,
         City= LocationDetails.city, State= LocationDetails.state, Country = LocationDetails.countryOrRegion

**      - Extract a Username from a User Principal Name (UPN) **

         AzureActivity
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(7d)
         | parse Caller with UPNUserPart "@" * //drop anything after the @ sign
         | where UPNUserPart != "" //Remove non UPN callers (apps, SPNs, etc)
         | distinct UPNUserPart, Caller


     Sample use cases:

**      - Identify a vulnerable host with a publicly exploitable vulnerability that also has suspicious file activity on it **

         let watchlst=(_GetWatchlist('Hva'))
         | project svrname;
         let secalert=(SecurityAlert
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(1d)
         | where AlertName contains "MTP File activity alert"
         | extend HostName_ = tostring(parse_json(Entities)[0].HostName)
          |extend AppendDom=strcat(HostName_,".contoso.azure"));
         secalert
         | join MDE_TVM_PublicExploits_CL on $left.AppendDom == $right.DeviceName_s
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(1d)
         | where VulnerabilitySeverityLevel_s == "High" and AppendHost in~ (watchlst)
         | distinct DisplayName, AlertSeverity, VulnerabilitySeverityLevel_s, VulnerabilityDescription_s

**      - Detect ransomware on a device protected by Microsoft Defender for Endpoint **

         SecurityAlert
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(1h)
         | where ProviderName =="MDATP" and Status in ("New", "Active")
         | where ExtendedProperties has "Ransomware"
         | extend Prop = parse_json(ExtendedProperties)
         | extend MDE_Category = Prop["MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category"]
         | where MDE_Category has "Ransomware"
         | extend Action = Prop.Action
         | extend ThreatName = Prop.ThreatName
         | extend HostName = extract_all('"HostName"\\s*:\\s*"([^"]*)"', Entities)
         | project MDE_Category, TimeGenerated, Action, ThreatName, VendorOriginalId, SystemAlertId, HostName

## 2. Extract elements from a Syslog message

     Operators to be used:

      **- [extend](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/extendoperator)**       **- [extract](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/extractfunction)**

     Sample queries:

**      - Extract URL from a Syslog message**

         Syslog
         | extend Url = extract("(http[s]?://(?:[a-zA-Z]|[0-9]|[$-_@.&+]|[!*\\(\\),]|(?:%[0-9a-fA-F][0-9a-fA-F]))+)", 1,SyslogMessage)

**      - Extract Domain from a Syslog message**

         Syslog
         | extend Domain = extract("(([A-Z]+ [a-z]{4,5}:\\/\\/)|[A-Z]+ )([^ :\\/]*)",3,SyslogMessage)

**      - Extract HTTP Status code from a Syslog message**

         Syslog
         HTTP_Status_Code = extract("(TCP_(([A-Z]+)(_[A-Z]+)*)|UDP_(([A-Z]+)(_[A-Z]+)*))/([0-9]{3})",8,SyslogMessage)


     Sample use cases:

**      - Extract IP and compare addresses from Syslog messages **

         let PrivateIPregex = @'^127\.|^10\.|^172\.1[6-9]\.|^172\.2[0-9]\.|^172\.3[0-1]\.|^192\.168\.';
         | where Facility contains "auth" and ProcessName =~ "sshd"
         let ssh_logins = Syslog         | where SyslogMessage has "Accepted"
         | extend SourceIP = extract("(([0-9]{1,3})\\.([0-9]{1,3})\\.([0-9]{1,3})\\.(([0-9]{1,3})))",1,SyslogMessage)
         | where isnotempty(SourceIP)
         | extend ipType = iff(SourceIP matches regex PrivateIPregex,"private" ,"public");ssh_logins
         | summarize privatecount=countif(ipType=="private"), publiccount=countif(ipType=="public") by HostName, HostIP, bin(EventTime, 1d)
         | summarize publicIPLoginHistory = make_list(pack('IPCount', publiccount, 'logon_time', EventTime)),
         privateIPLoginHistory = make_list(pack('IPCount', privatecount, 'logon_time', EventTime)) by HostName, HostIP

**      - Identify top 5 target accounts with failed logon attempts **

          let top5 = SecurityEvent
         | where EventID == 4625 and AccountType == 'User'
         | extend Account_Name = extract(@"^(.*\\)?([^@]*)(@.*)?$", 2, tolower(Account))
         | summarize Attempts = count() by Account_Name
         | where Account_Name != ""
         | top 5 by Attempts
         | summarize make_list(Account_Name);
         SecurityEvent
         | where EventID == 4625 and AccountType == 'User'
         | extend Name = extract(@"^(.*\\)?([^@]*)(@.*)?$", 2, tolower(Account))
         | extend Account_Name = iff(Name in (top5), Name, "Other")
         | where Account_Name != ""
         | summarize Attempts = count() by Account_Name

## 3. Create custom properties from string expressions

     Operators to be used:

      **- [extend](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/extendoperator)**       **- [split](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/splitfunction)**       **- [parse](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/parseoperator)**

     Sample queries:

**      - Extract multiple fields from block a block of text within a single field**

         AzureDiagnostics
         | where OperationName == "AzureFirewallThreatIntelLog"
         | parse msg_s with Protocol " request from " SourceIP ":" SourcePortInt:int " to " TargetIP ":" TargetPortInt:int *
         | parse msg_s with * ". Action: " Action "." Message
         | parse msg_s with Protocol2 " request from " SourceIP2 " to " TargetIP2 ". Action: " Action2
         | extend SourcePort = tostring(SourcePortInt),TargetPort = tostring(TargetPortInt)
         | extend Protocol = case(Protocol == "", Protocol2, Protocol),SourceIP = case(SourceIP == "", SourceIP2, SourceIP),
         TargetIP = case(TargetIP=="", TargetIP2, TargetIP),SourcePort = case(SourcePort == "", "N/A", SourcePort),
         TargetPort = case(TargetPort == "", "N/A", TargetPort)
         | sort by TimeGenerated desc
         | project TimeGenerated, msg_s, Protocol, SourceIP,SourcePort,TargetIP,TargetPort,Action,Message


**      - Create columns from a custom table text field**

         
Some log data collected by Azure Monitor will include multiple pieces of information in a single property. Parsing this data into multiple properties make it easier to use in queries. A common example is a custom log that collects an entire log entry with multiple values into a single property. By creating separate properties for the different values, you can search and aggregate on each. Mode details     **[here](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/azure-monitor/logs/parse-text)**

         GeoDataTest2_CL
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(7d)
         | extend CSVFields = split(RawData, ',')
         | extend EventTime = todatetime(CSVFields[0])
         | extend network_s = tostring(CSVFields[1])
         | extend longitude = tostring(CSVFields[2])
         | extend latitude = tostring(CSVFields[3])
         | extend accuracy = tostring(CSVFields[4])
         | extend continent = tostring(CSVFields[5])
         | extend country = tostring(CSVFields[6])
         | extend timezone = tostring(CSVFields[7])


     Sample use case:

**      - Lookup IP addresses against a GeoLookup list imported into a custom table **

         let GeoData=(GeoDataTest2_CL
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(1d)
         | extend CSVFields = split(RawData, ',')
         | extend EventTime = todatetime(CSVFields[0])
         | extend network_s = tostring(CSVFields[1])
         | extend longitude = tostring(CSVFields[2])
         | extend latitude = tostring(CSVFields[3])
         | extend accuracy = tostring(CSVFields[4])
         | extend continent = tostring(CSVFields[5])
         | extend country = tostring(CSVFields[6])
         | extend timezone = tostring(CSVFields[7])
         | project-away CSVFields);
         SecurityEvent
         | extend commonfield = 1
         | lookup (GeoData | extend commonfield = 1) on commonfield
         | summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated,*) by id_s
         | where ipv4_is_in_range(IpAddress,network_s)
         | project-away commonfield
         | project TimeGenerated, IpAddress, network_s, longitude, latitude, continent, country, timezone

Overview:

2. Change the case of the string in a field

content.json:
## 1. Type casting a field - Converting from one data type to another

     Operators to be used:

      **- [todynamic()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/parsejsonfunction)**
      **- [tostring()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/tostringfunction)**
      **- [todatetime()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/todatetimefunction)**
      **- [mv-expand](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/mvexpandoperator)**

     Sample Queries:

**      - Returns the Service DisplayName from the VM Processes**

         VMProcess
         | mv-expand Services
         | extend DN = tostring(Services.DisplayName)
         | project TimeGenerated, Computer, Description, DN, WorkingDirectory

**      - Returns the record at a specific time**

         SecurityEvent
         | where TimeGenerated == todatetime("2021-09-07T16:11:35.920Z")

**      - Returns the MTP Alert URL from the MDATP Alert in the SecurityAlerts table**

         SecurityAlert
         | where ProviderName == "MDATP"
         | mv-expand todynamic(ExtendedLinks)
         | extend URL = tostring(ExtendedLinks.Href)
         | project TimeGenerated, AlertName, MTP_URL, AlertSeverity, SystemAlertId, Description

     Sample Use Cases:

**      - Extract UserName from a json element from within an Array in the Windows Event**

         Event
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(3d)
         | where EventID == '55555'
         | mv-expand todynamic(RenderedDescription)
         | extend name = parse_json(RenderedDescription).UserName

**      - Extract the UserPrincipal Name from the Windows Security Event 411 **

         SecurityEvent
         | where EventID == 411
         | extend p = parse_xml(EventData)
         | extend Error = tostring(parse_json(tostring(parse_json(tostring(p.EventData)).Data))[2])
         | where Error contains "The user name or password is incorrect"
         | extend UPN = split(Error, "-")[0]

**      - List all comments added to Closed Incidents in Microsoft Sentinel from the past 24 hours**

         SecurityIncident
         | where Status == "Closed" and isnotempty(Comments)
         | mv-expand Comments
         | extend CommentCreationTime = todatetime(parse_json(Comments.createdTimeUtc))
         | where CommentCreationTime >= ago(24h)
         | summarize by IncidentName, tostring(Comments), ProviderIncidentId

## 2. Change the case of the string in a field

**      - Compare the Account Name in the Windows Security Event Logs with a Dynamic List of Accounts**

         let HVA_Computer = dynamic(["victim00","sql00","jbox00","dc01"]);
         SecurityEvent
         | extend Hostname = tolower(tostring(split(Computer,".")[0]))
         | where Hostname in (HVA_Computer)

# {Category}

Overview:

Logs from some Data sources (such as Firewall/VPN appliances/DNS and more) consist of IP addresses that are contextually relevant when looking for ambiguous/malicious behavior. KQL has some native commands that help deal with IP addresses to compare and/or match the IP addresses in the logs ingested. IP Addresses could potentially lead investigations that can be suggestive of compromises from specific Geographical locations, subnets and/or insider risk.
I want to:

links.linkLabel: 1. Match IP addresses in the ingested logs with a known IP subnet
2. Compare IP addresses in the ingested logs with a known IP subnet
3. Check if IP Addresses in the ingested log is a private network IP
4. Matching IP Addresses in a text field
5. Lookup IP Addresses against a GeoIP table

content.json:
## 1. Match IP addresses in the ingested logs with a known IP subnet

     Operators to be used:

      **- [ipv4_is_match()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/ipv4-is-matchfunction)**
      **- [ipv6_is_match()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/ipv6-is-matchfunction)**

Return Value

Translation

true

If the long representation of the first IPv4 string argument is equal to the second IPv4 string argument.

false

If the long representation of the first IPv4 string argument is NOT equal to the second IPv4 string argument.

null

If conversion for one of the two IPv4 strings wasn't successful.
      **[ipv4_is_in_range()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/ipv4-is-in-range-function)**

     Sample query:

**      - Populate a column if an IPv4 address is within a known network subnet**

         Heartbeat
         | extend HRSubnetIP = iif(ipv4_is_match(ComputerIP,"52.188.0.0", 16),"true","false")

     OR

         Heartbeat
         | extend HRSubnetIP = iif(ipv4_is_in_range(ComputerIP,"52.188.0.0/16") == 1,"true","false")

**      - Filter out 127.0.0.1 as Client IP from DNS Events**

         DnsEvents
         | where SubType =~ "LookupQuery"
         | where ipv4_is_match("127.0.0.1", ClientIP) == False

     Sample Use cases:

**      - Detect a Port Scan**

         let threshold = 50;
         SophosXGFirewall
         | where Log_Type =~ "Firewall"
         | where not(ipv4_is_match("10.0.0.0",Src_IP,8) or ipv4_is_match("172.16.0.0",Src_IP,12) or ipv4_is_match("192.168.0.0",Src_IP,16))
         | summarize dcount(Dst_Port) by Src_IP, bin(TimeGenerated, 5m)
         | where dcount_Dst_Port > threshold
         | extend timestamp = TimeGenerated, IPCustomEntity = Src_IP

Check out the relevant samples found in Microsoft Sentinel:

####       Analytics Rule:       **- [Port Scan Detected](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/06832a873e1686244f0bc02b10f79ba879078864/Detections/SophosXGFirewall/PortScanDetected.yaml)**
      **- [Potential DGA detected](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/76578d41f67181e6c1acb16b520f48a31d248036/Detections/DnsEvents/DNS_HighNXDomainCount_detection.yaml)** ####       Workbooks:       **- [Sophos XG Firewall](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/83c6d8c7f65a5f209f39f3e06eb2f7374fd8439c/Workbooks/SophosXGFirewall.json)**
      **- [Better Mobile Threat Defense (MTD)](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/1397ce50af10c32531a68a7a0e3b1b51b4304f4b/Workbooks/BETTER_MTD_Workbook.json)** ####       Hunting queries:       **- [Abnormally long DNS URI queries](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/76578d41f67181e6c1acb16b520f48a31d248036/Hunting%20Queries/DnsEvents/DNS_LongURILookup.yaml)**
      **- [Potential DGA detected](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/76578d41f67181e6c1acb16b520f48a31d248036/Hunting%20Queries/DnsEvents/DNS_HighPercentNXDomainCount.yaml)**

## 2. Compare IP addresses in the ingested logs with a known IP subnet

     Commands to be used:

      **- [ipv4_compare()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/ipv4-comparefunction)**
      **- [ipv6_compare()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/ipv6-comparefunction)**

Return Value

Translation

0

If the long representation of the first IPv4 string argument is equal to the second IPv4 string argument.

1

If the long representation of the first IPv4 string argument is greater than the second IPv4 string argument.

-1

If the long representation of the first IPv4 string argument is less than the second IPv4 string argument.

null

If conversion for one of the two IPv4 strings wasn't successful.

     Sample query:

**      - Populate a column if an IPv4 address is within a known network subnet**

         Heartbeat
         | extend HRSubnetIP = ipv4_compare(ComputerIP,"52.188.0.0", 16)
         | extend HRSubnetIP = iif((HRSubnetIP == 0), "true", "false")

**      - Tag communications as External/Internal based on IP Addresses**

         VMConnection
         | extend compare = ipv4_compare(DestinationIp,"10.0.0.0/8")
         | extend Channel = iif(compare != 0 and DestinationIp != "127.0.0.1","External","Internal")

## 3. Check if IP Addresses in the ingested log is a private network IP

     Commands to be used:

      **- [ipv4_is_private()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/ipv4-is-privatefunction)**

     Sample query:

**      - Check if an IP Address is private**

         W3CIISLog
         | extend IsPrivate = iif(ipv4_is_private(cIP),"true","false")

**      - Filter out all Public IPs from logs**

         AzureDiagnostics
         | where ipv4_is_private(primaryIPv4Address_s)

     Sample Use cases:

**      - Detect the presence of an External Proxy**

         Corelight
         | where EventType =~ 'http'
         | where isnotempty(HttpProxiedHeaders)
         | where ipv4_is_private(SrcIpAddr) == 'False'
         | extend IPCustomEntity = SrcIpAddr

Check out the relevant samples found in Microsoft Sentinel:

####       Analytics Rule:       **- [Ubiquiti - Large ICMP to external server](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/a6f6275b4ba79f8bfcefe7ae72afcb055a5bbf80/Solutions/Ubiquiti/Analytic%20Rules/UbiquitiL2RLargeIcmp.yaml)**
      **- [Corelight - External Proxy Detected](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/a6f6275b4ba79f8bfcefe7ae72afcb055a5bbf80/Solutions/Corelight/Analytic%20Rules/CorelightExternalProxyDetected.yaml)**
      **- [OracleDBAudit - Connection to database from external IP](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/a6f6275b4ba79f8bfcefe7ae72afcb055a5bbf80/Solutions/OracleDatabaseAudit/Analytic%20Rules/OracleDBAuditConnectFromExternalIp.yaml)**
      **- [Exchange SSRF Autodiscover ProxyShell - Detection](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/1ec69a144ea9e405de6cbbc4b109f7fa6d61c164/Detections/W3CIISLog/ProxyShellPwn2Own.yaml)**
####       Workbooks:       **- [Ubiquiti](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/83c6d8c7f65a5f209f39f3e06eb2f7374fd8439c/Solutions/Ubiquiti/Workbooks/Ubiquiti.json)** ####       Hunting Queries:       **- [Exchange Server Suspicious URIs Visited](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/158019e9f69d847f506d2f1ba05af0bad64b66dd/Hunting%20Queries/W3CIISLog/ExchangeServerSuspiciousURIsVisited.yaml)**
      **- [Ubiquiti - Hidden internal DNS server](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/83c6d8c7f65a5f209f39f3e06eb2f7374fd8439c/Solutions/Ubiquiti/Hunting%20Queries/UbiquitiInternalDnsServer.yaml)**
      **- [Suspected ProxyToken Exploitation](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/6d573b82c76896a8d077557e60e9d59d87034878/Hunting%20Queries/W3CIISLog/SuspectedProxyTokenExploitation.yaml)**
      **- [Exchange Server ProxyLogon URIs](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/158019e9f69d847f506d2f1ba05af0bad64b66dd/Hunting%20Queries/W3CIISLog/ExchangeServerProxyLogonURI.yaml)**

## 4. Matching IP Addresses in a text field

     Operators to be used:

      **- [has_ipv4()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/has-ipv4-function)**
      **- [has_any_ipv4()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/has-any-ipv4-function)**

     Sample query:

**      - Filter logs based on an IP Address**

         AzureDiagnostics
         | where Category contains "PeeringRouteLog"
         | where has_any_ipv4(nexthop_s,"192.168.12.41")

**      - Filter logs based on a list of IP Addresses**

         let IPList = dynamic(["192.168.12.41","192.168.12.45","10.71.2.13"]);
         AzureDiagnostics
         | where Category contains "PeeringRouteLog"
         | where has_any_ipv4(nexthop_s,IPList)

     Sample Use cases:

**      - Look for an IP Address match in multiple fields**

         CommonSecurityLog
         | where isnotempty(SourceIP) or isnotempty(DestinationIP)
         | where SourceIP in (IPList) or DestinationIP in (IPList) or has_any_ipv4 (Message, IPList)
         | extend IPMatch = case(
         SourceIP in (IPList), "SourceIP",
         DestinationIP in (IPList), "DestinationIP",
         "Message")

**      - Look for an IP Address match in Threat Intelligence Indicators**

         let SrcIP = ThreatIntelligenceIndicator
         | summarize SrcIPList = make_set(NetworkSourceIP);
         CommonSecurityLog
         | where isnotempty(SourceIP) or isnotempty(DestinationIP)
         | where SourceIP in (SrcIP) or DestinationIP in (SrcIP) or has_any_ipv4 (Message, toscalar(SrcIP))
         | extend IPMatch = case(SourceIP in (SrcIP), "SourceIP", DestinationIP in (SrcIP), "DestinationIP","Message")

Check out the relevant samples found in Microsoft Sentinel:

####       Analytics Rule:       **- [Manganese_VPN-IOCs](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/60866cf25e4af0cc1817a8d3fd1d94e53dd85853/Detections/MultipleDataSources/Manganese_VPN-IOCs.yaml)**

## 5. Lookup IP Addresses against a GeoIP table

     Operators to be used:

      **- [ipv4_lookup](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/ipv4-lookup-plugin)**
      **- [externaldata](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/externaldata-operator?pivots=azuredataexplorer)**

     Sample Use cases:

**      - Lookup IP Address in the Azure Activity table against a GeoIP table**

         let IP_Data =
         externaldata(network:string,geoname_id:long,continent_code:string,continent_name:string,
         country_iso_code:string,country_name:string,is_anonymous_proxy:bool,
         is_satellite_provider:bool)
         ['https://raw.githubusercontent.com/datasets/geoip2-ipv4/master/data/geoip2-ipv4.csv'];
         AzureActivity
         | where isnotempty(CallerIpAddress)
         | evaluate ipv4_lookup(IP_Data, CallerIpAddress, network, return_unmatched = true)
         | project TimeGenerated, Caller, CallerIpAddress, CategoryValue,OperationNameValue,
         ResourceProviderValue,ActivityStatusValue,ResourceGroup,continent_name,country_name

# {Category}

Overview:

Dealing/Manipulating fields is almost always required. Logs when ingested may contain information in some fields that need to be concatenated or split for better understanding and/or processing in security context for detections, reporting or hunting.
I want to:

links.linkLabel: 1. Concatenate field to form a single string and write it to a new column
2. Split characters from a string field and extract a part of it
4. Validate and/or filter on a field value being empty or null
5. Conditionally populate a field based on other values in logs

content.json:
## 1. Concatenate field to form a single string and write it to a new column

     Operators to be used:

      ** [strcat()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/strcatfunction)**

     Sample query:

**      - Concatenated string that uses constant string and values from Fields**

         DeviceInfo
         | extend Info = strcat("Device with Hostname",DeviceName," and
          Public IP Address ‚Äì", PublicIP," was found sending unusual traffic. Please investigate")

     Sample use cases:

**      - Identify when a password change occurs on a host **

         SecurityEvent
         | where EventID in (4723,4724)
         | summarize StartTimeUtc = min(TimeGenerated), EndTimeUtc = max(TimeGenerated),
         ResultDescriptions = makeset(Activity), ActionCount = count() by Resource = Computer,
         OperationName = strcat("TargetAccount: ", TargetUserName),
         UserId = Account, Type

Check out the relevant samples found in Microsoft Sentinel:

####       Analytics Rule:       **- [Anomalous sign-in location by user account and authenticating application](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/06832a873e1686244f0bc02b10f79ba879078864/Detections/SigninLogs/AnomalousUserAppSigninLocationIncrease-detection.yaml)**
      **- [Azure DevOps Service Conection Abuse](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/06832a873e1686244f0bc02b10f79ba879078864/Detections/AzureDevOpsAuditing/AzDOServiceConnectionUsage.yaml)**
      **- [Correlate Unfamiliar sign-in properties and atypical travel alerts](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/ade86a8cf8026f3a3e3ad28be8a5e89aa1479067/Detections/SecurityAlert/CorrelateIPC_Unfamiliar-Atypical.yaml)**
####       Workbooks:       **- [Azure Active Directory Signin Logs](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/403cff4851d7712b4c524f287a483de84f7db34b/Workbooks/AzureActiveDirectorySignins.json)**
      **- [Analytics Efficiency](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/f4133f38e2bc3f964c8e1de22db27d0ff5536986/Workbooks/AnalyticsEfficiency.json)**
      **- [Azure DDoS Standard Workbook](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/83c6d8c7f65a5f209f39f3e06eb2f7374fd8439c/Workbooks/AzDDoSStandardWorkbook.json)**
      **- [AKS Security](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/368ddf53f09a09610f57ec74118f678935dcda73/Workbooks/AksSecurity.json)** ####       Hunting Queries:       **- [Abnormally long DNS URI queries](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/76578d41f67181e6c1acb16b520f48a31d248036/Hunting%20Queries/DnsEvents/DNS_LongURILookup.yaml)**
      **- [Tracking Privileged Account Rare Activity](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/c69fda6e8b90aa3ae797560b670a42fa8fce2859/Hunting%20Queries/MultipleDataSources/TrackingPrivAccounts.yaml)**
      **- [Solorigate DNS Pattern](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/83c6d8c7f65a5f209f39f3e06eb2f7374fd8439c/Hunting%20Queries/DnsEvents/Solorigate-DNS-Pattern.yaml)**
      **- [Azure Active Directory sign-in burst from multiple locations](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/158019e9f69d847f506d2f1ba05af0bad64b66dd/Hunting%20Queries/SigninLogs/signinBurstFromMultipleLocations.yaml)**

## 2. Split characters from a string field and extract a part of it.

     Operators to be used:

      ** [split()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/splitfunction)**

     Sample query:

**      - Split the FQDN and extract the hostname**

         SecurityEvent
         | extend Hostname = tostring(split(Computer,".")[0])
         | project TimeGenerated, Hostname, Account, AccountType, EventSourceName,
         EventID, Activity

**      - Split the Account field and extract the Account Name**

         SecurityEvent
         | extend AccountName = tostring(split(Account,"\\\")[1])
         | project TimeGenerated, Hostname, Account, AccountType, EventSourceName,
         EventID, Activity

     Sample use cases:

**      - Identify user account interactive logons to new devices **

         let cloudApiTerms = dynamic(["api", "east", "west"]);
         DnsEvents
         | where Name endswith ".com" or Name endswith ".org" or Name endswith ".net"
         | extend domain_split = split(Name, ".")
         | where tostring(domain_split[-5]) != "" and tostring(domain_split[-6]) == ""
         | extend sub_domain = tostring(domain_split[0])
         | where sub_domain !contains "-"
         | extend sub_directories = strcat(domain_split[-3], " ", domain_split[-4])
         | where ActionType == "InteractiveLogon" and
         | where sub_directories has_any(cloudApiTerms)
         //Based on sample communications the subdomain is always between 20 and 30 bytes
         | where strlen(sub_domain) < 32 and strlen(sub_domain) > 20
         | extend domain = strcat(tostring(domain_split[-2]), ".", tostring(domain_split[-1]))
         | extend subdomain_no = countof(sub_domain, @"(\d)", "regex")
         | extend subdomain_ch = countof(sub_domain, @"([a-z])", "regex")
         | where subdomain_no > 1
         | extend percentage_numerical = toreal(subdomain_no) / toreal(strlen(sub_domain)) * 100
         | where percentage_numerical < 50 and percentage_numerical > 5
         | summarize count(), make_set(Name), FirstSeen=min(TimeGenerated),
         LastSeen=max(TimeGenerated) by Name
         | order by count_ asc
         | extend timestamp = FirstSeen

## 3. Conditionally write in a column

     Operators to be used:

      ** [iif()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/iiffunction)**

     Sample query:

**      - Report of Windows machines that are/are not Protected by Windows Defender**

         ProtectionStatus
         | where OSName != "Linux"
         | extend WinDefenderStatus = iif(TypeofProtection == "Windows
         Defender","Enabled","Unknown")
         | project Computer, ComputerIP_Hidden, WinDefenderStatus, OSName, ThreatStatus,
         ThreatStatusRank

     Sample use cases:

**      - Count Number of Logon and Logoff events for a host in the last 12 hours**

         SecurityEvent
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(12h)
         | where Computer contains "DC00"
         | extend EventType = iif(EventID == 4624,"Successful Logon", iif(EventID == 4634,"Successful
         logoff",""))
         | where isnotempty(EventType)
         | summarize Count = count() by EventType

## 4. Validate and/or filter on a field value being empty or null

     Operators to be used:

      ** [isempty()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/isemptyfunction)** or **[isnotempty()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/isnotemptyfunction)**
      ** [isnull()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/isnullfunction)** or **[isnotnull()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/isnotnullfunction)**

     Sample query:

**      - Filter out records where the EventData field doesn't have a value in the Windows Security Events**

         SecurityEvent
         | where isnotempty(EventData)
         | extend IsDomainAccount = iif(Account startswith "Contoso","True","False")
         | project TimeGenerated, IsDomainAccount, Account, AccountType, EventSourceName,
         EventID, Activity


**      - Filter out records where the OfficeObjectID field have a value in the Office365 logs**

         OfficeActivity
         | where isempty(OfficeObjectId)
         | sort by TimeGenerated desc nulls last


**      - Filter out records where the Event ID = 4688 and ParentProcessName field have a null value in the Windows Security Events**

         SecurityEvent
         | where EventID == 4688 and isnotnull(ParentProcessName)

     Sample use cases:

**      - Check for a known IP IoC in the Azure AD SignIn Logs **

         let IPList = dynamic(["154.223.45.38","185.141.207.140","185.234.73.19",
         "216.245.210.106","51.91.48.210","46.255.230.229"]);
         (union isfuzzy=true
          (SigninLogs
          | where isnotempty(IPAddress)
          | where IPAddress in (IPList)
          | extend timestamp = TimeGenerated, AccountCustomEntity = UserPrincipalName,
         IPCustomEntity = IPAddress
          ),
          (AADNonInteractiveUserSignInLogs
          | where isnotempty(IPAddress)
          | where IPAddress in (IPList)
          | extend timestamp = TimeGenerated, AccountCustomEntity = UserPrincipalName,
         IPCustomEntity = IPAddress
          )
         )


**      - Check for least common Parent And Child Process Pairs within the Security Events collected from the Windows Security Events**

         let Allowlist = dynamic (['foo.exe', 'baz.exe']);
         let Sensitivity = 5;
         SecurityEvent
         | where EventID == 4688 and isnotnull(ParentProcessName)
         | extend ProcArray = split(NewProcessName, '\\'), ParentProcArray = split(ParentProcessName,
         '\\')
         // ProcArrayLength is Folder Depth
         | extend ProcArrayLength = arraylength(ProcArray), ParentProcArrayLength =
         arraylength(ParentProcArray)
         | extend LastIndex = ProcArrayLength - 1, ParentLastIndex = ParentProcArrayLength - 1
         | extend Proc = ProcArray[LastIndex], ParentProc = ParentProcArray[ParentLastIndex]
         | where Proc !in (Allowlist)
         | extend ParentChildPair = strcat(ParentProc , ' > ', Proc)
         | summarize StartTimeUtc = min(TimeGenerated), EndTimeUtc = max(TimeGenerated),
         TimesSeen = count(), HostCount = dcount(Computer), Hosts = makeset(Computer),
         UserCount = dcount(SubjectUserName),
         Users = makeset(SubjectUserName) by ParentChildPair
         | where TimesSeen < Sensitivity

## 5. Conditionally use field values to populate/project a field

     Operators to be used:

      ** [case()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/casefunction)**
      ** [column_ifexists()](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/columnifexists)**

     Sample query:

**      - List Business orgs based on Source IPs**

         AzureDiagnostics
         | extend BusinessOrg = case(ipv4_is_match(primaryIPv4Address_s,"10.2.2.0/8"),"HR",
         ipv4_is_match(primaryIPv4Address_s,"10.71.0.0/8"),"IT",ipv4_is_match(primaryIPv4Address_s,
         "172.18.0.4"),"Finance","Operations")


**      - Create and update a field value based on a value from another column if it exists, or else, use a default value**

         AzureDiagnostics
         | extend RuleName = column_ifexists('ruleName_s',""),
                  MACAddress = column_ifexists('macAddress_s',"")
         | project TimeGenerated, Category, OperationName, RuleName, MACAddress

     Sample use cases:

**      - Order Security Alerts based on Severity (High to Low) **

         SecurityAlert
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(7d)
         | extend severityOrder = case (
          AlertSeverity == "High", 3,
          AlertSeverity == "Medium", 2,
          AlertSeverity == "Low", 1,
          AlertSeverity == "Informational", 0,
           -1)
          | order by severityOrder
          | where IPAddress in (IPList)
          | project-away severityOrder

# {Category}

Overview:

Watchlists are lookup lists in Microsoft Sentinel that can be used for correlation with the events in the Microsoft Sentinel environment. Once created, these can be used in search, detection rules, threat hunting and automated responses. Common scenarios for using watchlists include: 1. Investigating threats and responding to incidents quickly with the rapid import of IP addresses, file hashes, and other data from CSV files. Once imported, you can use watchlist name-value pairs for joins and filters in alert rules, threat hunting, workbooks, notebooks, and general queries. 2. Importing business data as a watchlist. For example, import user lists with privileged system access, or terminated employees, and then use the watchlist to create allowlists and blocklists used to detect or prevent those users from logging in to the network. 3. Reducing alert fatigue. Create allowlists to suppress alerts from a group of users, such as users from authorized IP addresses that perform tasks that would normally trigger the alert, and prevent benign events from becoming alerts. 4. Enriching event data. Use watchlists to enrich your event data with name-value combinations derived from external data sources. [Use Microsoft Sentinel Watchlists](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/kusto/query/ingestiontimefunctionhttps://docs.microsoft.com/azure/sentinel/watchlists)

content.json:
## 1. List items in a Watchlist Retrieving Watchlist items from the Log Analytics Workspace.

     Operators to be used:

      ** _GetWatchlist()**
      More details on using using Watchlists in queries available ** [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/sentinel/watchlists#use-watchlists-in-queries)**

     Sample query:

**      - Returns top 10 watchlist items after sorting the entire watchlist by TimeGenerated**

         _GetWatchlist('ipwatchlist')
         | sort by TimeGenerated desc nulls last
         | top 10

**      - Returns all Watchlist items added in the last 24 hours **

         _GetWatchlist('ipwatchlist')
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(24h)

## 2. Correlate Watchlist items

     Operators to be used:

      ** _GetWatchlist()**
        More details on using using Watchlists in queries available ** [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/sentinel/watchlists#use-watchlists-in-queries)**        ‚Ä¢ Data in any table can be queried against data from a watchlist by treating the watchlist as a table for joins and lookups.

     Sample query:

**      - Returns the records that match the IPs from a Watchlist**

         Heartbeat
         | lookup kind=leftouter _GetWatchlist('mywatchlist') on $left.RemoteIPCountry == $right.SearchKey


**      - Alert if item found in Watchlist**

         let UserList = _GetWatchlist('users')
         | summarize make_set(Email);
         AzureActivity
         | where Caller in (UserList)


**      - Alert if item not found in Watchlist**

         AzureActivity
         | join kind = leftanti _GetWatchlist('users') on $left.Caller == $right.Email


     Sample use cases:

**      - Known Malicious IP found in MCAS Logs**

         let ipioc = _GetWatchlist('badips') | summarize make_list('IpAddress');
         McasShadowItReporting
         | where IpAddress in (ipioc)
         | project TimeGenerated, EnrichedUserName, AppName, AppCategory, AppScore


**      - Monitor users running Log Analytics queries that contain filters for VIPUser watchlist**

         LAQueryLogs
         | where QueryText has_any ("_GetWatchlist('VIPUsers')")
         | project TimeGenerated, AADEmail, RequestClientApp, QueryText, ResponseRowCount, RequestTarget
         | extend timestamp = TimeGenerated, AccountCustomEntity = AADEmail

Check out the relevant samples found in Microsoft Sentinel:

####       Analytics Rule:       **- [SAP ‚Äì Security Audit Log Configuration Change](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/tree/645bad572223880eaf8bd79989ef1fe8e5b2a3f0/Solutions/SAP/Analytics)** ####       Workbooks:       **- [Incident Overview Workbook](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/0a4d50238b8d6dfc342d8275465d62c3c55a2444/Workbooks/IncidentOverview.json)**       **- [SOC Process Framework Workbook](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/blob/c382e7b782bd9fe1622ae757068f32e88d96b988/Workbooks/SOCProcessFramework.json)**

## 3. Get Watchlist Aliases in Microsoft Sentinel To get a list of watchlist aliases from the Azure portal, the **[_GetWatchlistAlias](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/sentinel/watchlists#view-list-of-watchlists-aliases)** operator can be run by navigating to Microsoft Sentinel > General > Logs and running the _GetWatchlistAlias operator without any arguments.

     Sample query:

**      - Returns 10 watchlist aliases configured in Microsoft Sentinel**

         _GetWatchlistAlias
         | take 10

**      - Returns all Watchlists aliases that have the string VIP in the Alias configured in Microsoft Sentinel**

         _GetWatchlistAlias
         | where WatchlistAlias contains "VIP"

## 4. Correlate entities with UEBA Watchlists for Behavioral Analytics Microsoft Sentinel now comes with Built-in watchlists templates for UEBA data which can be customized. These can then be correlated with analytic rules, view it in the entity pages and investigation graphs as insights, create custom uses such as to track VIP or sensitive users and more.

     Sample query:

**      - Correlate High-Value Assets Watchlist with Security Events**

         let HVA = _GetWatchlist('HighValueAssets')
         | extend AssetFQDN = tolower('Asset FQDN');
         SecurityEvent
         | where EventID == 4624
         | extend Computer = tolower(Computer)
         | join kind = inner HVA on $left.Computer == $right.AssetFQDN

**      - Correlate Service Accounts' logon activity with Security Events**

         let ServiceAccounts = _GetWatchlist('ServiceAccounts')
         | extend sAMAccountName = tolower(tostring(split('Service Principal Name',"@")[0]));
         SecurityEvent
         | where EventID == 4624
         | extend Account = tolower(tostring(split(Account,"\\\")[1]))
         | join kind = inner ServiceAccounts on $left.Account == $right.sAMAccountName

     Sample Use cases:

**      - Alert on malicious file activity around a high value Assets that also have identified vulnerabiites**

         let watchlst=(_GetWatchlist('Hva')) | project svrname;
         let secalert=(SecurityAlert
         |where TimeGenerated > ago(1d)
         |where AlertName contains "MTP File activity alert"
         |extend HostName_ = tostring(parse_json(Entities)[0].HostName)
         |extend AppendDom=strcat(HostName_,".contoso.azure"));
         secalert
         | join MDE_TVM_PublicExploits_CL on $left.AppendDom == $right.DeviceName_s
         | where TimeGenerated > ago(1d)
         | where VulnerabilitySeverityLevel_s == "High" and AppendHost in~ (watchlst)
         | distinct DisplayName, AlertSeverity, VulnerabilitySeverityLevel_s, VulnerabilityDescription_s
